action.action-desc: Mr. Franks of Arizona (for himself and Mr. Sessions) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Homeland Security

form.official-title: To amend the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to secure critical infrastructure against electromagnetic threats, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Critical Infrastructure Protection Act or the CIPA.

section.header: EMP planning, research and development, and protection and preparedness

subsection.text: The Homeland Security Act of 2002 (6 U.S.C. 121) is amended—

paragraph.text: in section 2 (6 U.S.C. 101), by inserting after paragraph (6) the following:
The term EM threat means an electromagnetic pulse caused by—

subparagraph.text: a nuclear device or nonnuclear device, including such a pulse caused by an act of terrorism; or
a geomagnetic disturbance or other naturally occurring phenomenon.

paragraph.text: in title V (6 U.S.C. 311 et seq.), by adding at the end the following:

section.text: The Secretary, acting through the Assistant Secretary of the National Protection and Programs Directorate, shall—

paragraph.text: include EM threats in national planning scenarios; and
conduct a campaign to proactively educate owners and operators of critical infrastructure, emergency planners, and emergency responders at all levels of government of EM threats.
in title III (6 U.S.C. 181 et seq.), by adding at the end of the following:

subsection.text: In furtherance of domestic preparedness and response, the Secretary, acting through the Under Secretary for Science and Technology, and in consultation with other relevant agencies and departments of the Federal Government and relevant owners and operators of critical infrastructure, shall conduct research and development to mitigate the consequences of EM threats.
The scope of the research and development under subsection (a) shall include the following:

paragraph.text: An objective scientific analysis of the risks to critical infrastructures from a range of EM threats.
Determination of the critical national security assets and vital civic utilities and infrastructures that are at risk from EM threats.

An evaluation of emergency planning and response technologies that would address the findings and recommendations of experts, including those of the Commission to Assess the Threat to the United States from Electromagnetic Pulse Attack.
An analysis of technology options that are available to improve the resiliency of critical infrastructure to EM threats.
The restoration and recovery capabilities of critical infrastructure under differing levels of damage and disruption from various EM threats.
in section 201(d) (6 U.S.C. 121(d)), by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.text: Prepare and submit to the Committee on Homeland Security of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate—

clause.text: a comprehensive plan to protect and prepare the critical infrastructure of the American homeland against EM threats, including from acts of terrorism; and
be based on findings of the research and development conducted under section 318;
be developed in consultation with the relevant Federal sector-specific agencies (as defined under Homeland Security Presidential Directive–7) for critical infrastructures;
be developed in consultation with the relevant sector coordinating councils for critical infrastructures; and

subsection.text: The table of contents in section 1(b) of such Act is amended—

paragraph.text: by adding at the end of the items relating to title V the following:

toc.toc-entry: Sec. 526. National planning scenarios and education.

paragraph.text: by adding at the end of the items relating to title III the following:

subsection.text: The Secretary of Homeland Security shall submit the comprehensive plan required under the amendment made by subsection (a)(4) by not later than one year after the date of the enactment of this Act.

The Secretary shall submit a report to Congress by not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act describing the progress made in, and an estimated date by which the Department of Homeland Security will have completed—

paragraph.text: including EM threats (as defined in the amendment made by subsection (a)(1)) in national planning scenarios;
research and development described in the amendment made by subsection (a)(3);
development of the comprehensive plan required under the amendment made by subsection (a)(4); and
beginning a campaign to proactively educate emergency planners and emergency responders at all levels of government regarding EM threat events.

section.text: Nothing in this Act, including the amendments made by this Act, shall be construed to grant any regulatory authority.
This Act, including the amendments made by this Act, may be carried out only by using funds appropriated under the authority of other laws.
